asset.data: March was a significant month for me; it marked the month of my first birthday subsequent to leaving school, but also marked the culmination and fulfillment of my most demanding <Italic>dream</Italic> to date  receiving admittance into Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). While initially, I saw this as a personal accomplishment, after receiving a flurry of congratulatory words, I realized this achievement was bigger than me  it was a win for my family but more importantly the youth of South Africa. The truth of the matter is that to some, this accomplishment has made me a role model, and while I had not envisioned or even explicitly sought for this status, I've come to recognize that with this entitlement, also comes expectations on my part.

South Africa is currently stationary  we have come a long way since Apartheid, but find ourselves tackling newer problems each day  and what we need to stimulate its movement again are young, bright, creative minds who strive to improve the state of the country. I believe these minds are out there, but only need stimulus and the right motivation to realize their potential; this is where young people like <Link src={'http://www.news24.com/MyNews24/The-amazing-journey-of-Siyabulela-Xuza-20150301'}>Siya Xuza</Link>, and to a lesser extent, myself come in. People find encouragement in the success stories of people no different to them, and as a result, I find that I have a responsibility to use my platform and successes to create a positive influence on the youth, so that one boy's successes can result in the successes of hundreds of people like myself.

This document details some of the ways in which I plan to interact and empower younger people like myself to bring about change in our nation. Due to the fact that I am pursuing a career in engineering, and subsequently the world of manufacturing, you might find that many of my solutions are partial towards engineering and technology, especially in how they can benefit South Africa today. This inclination will become apparent in ensuing paragraphs.

It all begins with a dream. The important thing to note is that it doesn't matter how outlandish the dream may be, because if one puts enough effort into it, chances are that it will become a reality. This is communicated no better than the following quote:
Never let it be said that to dream is a waste of one's time, for dreams are our realities in waiting. In dreams, we plant the seeds of our future.

I want to encourage others to dream big, to expose them to the possibilities out there and to spark an interest in altruistic pursuits that can have a significant impact on South Africa; I find many people base their career choices on the pursuance of wealth as opposed to their passions and the overall impact of the career on society. I also want to help them cultivate their interests and garner the relevant skills. I can briefly relate this to my own situation:

A few years ago, I read an article about an eleven year-old boy, <Link src={'http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/jacob-barnett-experts-said-boy-1895692'}>Jacob Barnett</Link>, who through following his passions, had enrolled into university at his tender age to study Physics; he is currently pioneering new research that could make a significant impact on humanity as a whole. I was dumbfounded by this story, to the point that it became my stimulus  what made me what to make an impact, but in the best possible way I could do so. I've always been interested in processes that allow one the ability to convert abstract thought into tangible products, such as painting or composing music, and after pensive thought and a deep analysis of my skill set, interests and the current professional needs of South Africa, I landed upon engineering.
I chose engineering based on three motives:

data: I noticed that as a country (and as a continent), we are primarily a consumer  we consume what other's produce and produce very little of our own goods. This is because we have relied primarily on the minerals of our land to provide income for us, however this isn't sustainable. This is why other mineral-based countries like the United Arab Emirates have started finding successful substitutes to commodity trading, (in their case Tourism). However, we have not found a viable substitute. I see that substitute in manufacturing.

Secondly, I acknowledged that as an engineer, I could actively help solve our continents problems, as this is the primary objective of engineering: to create solutions to our current day-to-day problems through the application of knowledge and the use of technology.
Lastly, I saw engineering simply as an alternate medium in which my fundamental passion could be exercised, so the profession suited my interests.

asset.data: After deciding upon a profession with which I could make the biggest impact, I was left with the task of how to cultivate the skills needed to become the best possible artisan in the line of work I want to pursue - this pointed to education. However through research, I saw that the universities in South Africa were quite behind when it came to new innovations in technology, and coupled along with the fact that they seemed to be more theoretically based, as opposed to being equally practical, I decided that it would be best to look at where the innovations occur and where education is founded on practical learning (applying theory learnt in class to practical projects). This led me to MIT. Had MIT been in South Africa, I would have not pursued an education overseas, however it isn't, so in order for me to develop the skills required to be a first-class engineer, I felt I had to go there.

If I look at my own experience, it seems that the whole process of developing that desired mindset could be divided into a three-part process. It begins with stimulating an altruistic dream, followed by cultivating and strengthening the interest, and summed up by finding the best methods with which to develop yourself to use your skills to make an impact on South Africa. It's important to be mindful of one's interests, skill set and the professional needs of the country during this process to ensure one has made the right choices. The initiatives outlined below follow a similar progression. They can be applied to many professions, but these one's a focused on engineering, and how its increased role in South Africa could make an impact economically and socially. I have thought of effective ways with which to spark an interest in engineering within the youth (in South Africa, in particular), and to cultivate these interests and support them, so that many more youthful people can be exposed to the potential of engineering and technology, and its role in improving our nation.

In reaching out and motivating the South African youth, the first idea deals with ways to elicit an interest in engineering as a potential profession, and the idea stems from my own experience in how I came to find a solace in engineering, which as I noted was through reading stories about people my age performing extraordinary feats (Jacob Barnett). A lot of today's youth make use of the Internet as a medium of communication and information retrieval; because so many people are connected to the internet, I believe it can be used as an effective way disseminate information. As a user of the Internet, its problem lies in the fact that it is so vast, which makes it difficult to acquire concise and relevant information. What I propose is an all-in-one website dedicated to technology with relevance to South Africa  a page where young people can visit to learn about the latest technologies and how they can improve our standards of living, to read inspirational stories about people our age performing great feats, to be exposed to interesting websites and hobbyist projects (such as the <Link src={'http://arduino.cc/'}>Arduino</Link>), and get a sense of where the technological world is heading. The website has to take advantage of other social media, such as Twitter and Facebook, to get people talking and to connect more people to the page. I understand that this website solution isn't a new idea, but I believe it is an effect one.

From my observations, very few people pursue engineering as a profession because of its public image. Because it is mathematical and scientifically rooted, engineering is seen as ‘nerdy', but the important detail lies in people's views of math and science. Many people find mathematics and the sciences boring and difficult, and I believe this stems from the fact that these people are rarely exposed to the practical applications of what they are learning, which makes the work feel irrelevant and therefore boring. Similarly, because they've lost interest in the subjects, they tend to find the work difficult because they don't have an interest in applying themselves to it. With this website I want to re-brand mathematics and sciences to the youth as tools with which they can reshape our landscape. The key lies in the fact that I will attempt to make it more palatable for the masses, so that any person somewhat interested in the information can understand it. This is the first step in sparking interest and stimulating dreaming about solving our countries problems with engineering.

Through my own efforts and experiences, I have found that there are very few places in South Africa where the youth can apply what they learn at school. What I mean is that we have very few hobbyist shops or instructional workshops available where young people can go to build things and practically apply mathematics and science they learn. The teaching methods at schools and universities are very theoretically based, so students hardly get practical experience until later in their studies. I've noticed the consequences of this at the University of Cape Town this year, where I've seen that very few people who have chosen engineering as a profession have been exposed to actual electronics, and consequently find it difficult to cope with it, as a subject. Furthermore, I've noted many people who have chosen engineering as a profession, realize only late into their studies that they don't enjoy it because they had never been exposed to it, in their lives, before. These people often leave engineering to rather apply their analytical skills in business management roles. The converse might also happen, where people who have never been exposed to engineering possibly could have enjoyed it and even excelled in the discipline, but never had the chance to because they were not exposed to it.

The second idea is to set up workshops, during the school holidays, where the youth in high school, or earlier, can learn about electronics and building - much like going to a visual art workshop to learn how to draw. I've only recently been exposed to platforms designed to teach people about electronics, such as <Link src={'http://arduino.cc/'}>Arduino</Link> and <Link src={'https://www.raspberrypi.org/'}>Raspberry Pi</Link>. These platforms could be taught at the workshops. The beauty of these platforms is that they allow people to create a range of amazing products, but require a solid foundation in mathematics to create the really “over-the-top” products. This would create a desire to apply mathematics practically outside of the class environment, much like it did with me.

This would get more people applying their knowledge while simultaneously encourage more people to learn the sciences. I propose to initially begin teaching these workshops myself to a small group of people during my summer holidays; the most practical place would be in Johannesburg where I reside. Obviously, one complication comes in the form of accessibility  it will be difficult for many other aspiring attendees from throughout the country to attend. To resolve this, I could film the workshops and broadcast them on the previously proposed website with a list of the items needed to complete projects. Through this, more people will be exposed to true engineering  which might encourage people to engage in mathematics and science  assisted to cultivate the relevant skills, and helped to make more informed decisions about choosing engineering as a potential profession. As time progresses and the idea catches on, these workshops could be made larger and placed in more areas.

Finally, the last idea involves possibly setting up some form of a foundation intent on helping aspiring engineers develop the relevant skills through the provision of specific services and information. Some of the duties of the foundation could be to identify talent, to connect aspiring engineers to firms in need of bright minds, to conduct talks about engineering as a profession, to help students who are seeking to study overseas, to run electronics workshops, and to facilitate in exchange programs with overseas universities for both students and lecturers. The exchange programs could help to expose more students and lecturers to the methods of teaching used elsewhere to help improve the methods we currently use here. The foundation could possibly be involved with Eskom, particularly in its Expo for Young Scientists, where it could identify new talent and help guide them. By going to MIT, I will also be opening up networking possibilities for both students and lecturers alike in South Africa; from these, I could possibly facilitate in organizing mentorship opportunities between scholars from there and from our universities. This foundation could visit different schools and conduct talks directed at the younger grades, such as Grade 9, and expose them to the “mysterious” field of engineering. I recall not knowing much about engineering in Grade 9, so I think it would be great to expose it these younger students, especially if it is done with examples of actual engineering projects.

In conclusion, how can these initiatives help in getting our country moving again? The strategies outlined will encourage more people to enjoy mathematics and science, which in turn will influence more people to choose engineering as a profession. Through providing many avenues with which to practically apply knowledge, the initiatives will develop creative minds and aid in producing qualified engineers. Having more engineers who are passionate about creating will not only boosts our manufacturing sector, but will potentially expedite solutions to South Africa's and the African continent's biggest problems, through the use of technology. As a bonus, it is likely more people will open up their own businesses  “start-ups”  to market their new ideas, which could aid in alleviating our poverty problem. I believe that through these tactical strategies, South Africa will be well on its way to becoming a producer as opposed to just being the consumer, and will be in a better position to solving its current economic and social problems.

asset.data: I don't exist.

Immersed in my own thoughts, I sit quietly in the company of well-groomed men and women that are joined at hand, who in this transient moment are united in synchronized movement - bouncing to the serene rhythm of the tune that surrounds us. I feel deplorably bound to these four wooden legs  still and painfully immobile. The congregation, in their graceful spring, orbit me like planets would around a glistening star; it is as if they are drawn by my pull, but in actuality, it is I who is drawn to them. I long for such amity.

I don't recall a time when I didn't feel this detachment from my environment; in fact, I've always been the black sheep. It's baffling because, as humans, we have an innate inclination to form bonds with other beings; I must have been overlooked, because it's a concept I have never fully grasped. I've always felt like the indigent child peering into a high-end store  close enough to view what appears to be bliss, but never close enough to experience it first-hand. Hindered by a mere window, I've been left to walk the lonely, melancholic streets of solitude.

I don't disparage solitude, but there is only so long one has the ability to resist one's innate instinct. After time, what once appeared to be one's solace ends up becoming one's shortcoming. It's a difficult feeling for one to carry, because it's emotionally straining, but simultaneously there also comes a physical suffering. It's one of the most abstract feelings I've had to describe, but it's as if your heart is being tightly held between two hands  they are hampering your flow of blood and slowly robbing you of your lifeline. The worst part is that one senses the discomfort, the heaviness, but is unable to remedy the uneasiness. It is self-inflected.

There is only one remedy, and it's reintegration. The only way to alleviate my heart's pain is to tread back into grounds that seem foreign to me now. For some, this task might appear trivial, but for someone who has been immersed in their own world for the extent of time that I have, it becomes a daunting challenge. Like an animal that has been kept in gloomy captivity, treading into the light, after adapting to shadows, becomes unnerving. This task takes on the form of a tug of war: one is outmatched by one's rival, dejection, and while one tries effortlessly to win the war, a prompt stall sees one's progression slipping further and further away, until  the line is crossed.

They've stopped, and I've been seized from my solace back into reality. I still appear to be unnoticeable. Perhaps I'm looking through a one-way window that allows me to look in and witness the splendour, but prevents them from seeing my world. I don't criticize them; there is very little to see. But, I could be wrong. There is the slightest chance that I am seeing this backwards. Are they the one's blind to the splendour I take for granted on my side of the window? It all leads to one critical question  am I the outsider or the outlier?

outsider.subtitle: A fictional written piece about the struggles of solitude.
outsider.title: The Internal Story of an Outsider

asset.data: As a graduating senior in high school, when probed by my elders and peers about my professional goals and plans for the future, my response always elicited confused reactions. Many people would not associate a Computer Science career with a student who, until then, had flourished in the fields of Visual Art and Music. Their reactions came as no surprise to me. Although I excelled in the sciences, many saw my foray into the engineering field as a waste of my other talents; I mean, isn't engineering the antithesis of the arts? Since then, I've come up with many explanations that have justified my decision, but I think the following quote best explains my decision:
Creating things with your hands, or creating code, creating programs, are just different ways to express creativity.

To me, painting, composing, and programming are all analogous, however they differ in tools and medium. In painting, you make use of paintbrushes (your tools) to apply paint (your medium) to a blank canvas (your product), while programming makes use of programming languages/frameworks (your tools) to write programs (your product) using code (your medium). However, in both cases, one creates something beautifully complex out of simple, elementary tools. Three years have elapsed since then, and in that time I've picked up a few skills from the world of computer science  especially in the realm of web development. However, up until this point, I had had difficulty finding the right paintbrush necessary for building user interfaces. Nothing I'd come across was clean, intuitive, or fun to use.
paint_screen

As a beginner programmer, my front-end stack comprised of CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) and jQuery (a JavaScript library that makes DOM manipulation easier for developers). With these technologies, I soon noticed that there was a very low scope with which I could create rich applications and user experiences. Overwhelmed by the plethora or frameworks out there, a friend recommended I try out the MEAN stack, an open source software stack used to build dynamic websites and web applications. In simpler terms, the MEAN stack makes use of four technologies to build web applications: MongoDB (a NoSQL database), Express.js (a web application framework that runs on Node.js), and Node.js (an execution environment for event-driven server-side and networking applications) for server-side concerns, and Angular.js (a JavaScript MVC framework that runs in browser JavaScript engines) for client-side concerns.
mean_block_diagram

As “state-of-the-art” as I found this programming paradigm, I was not particularly wooed by it's complexity  complexity that made it non-intuitive to the intermediate developer. With a focus on the front-end programming, I found Angular extremely difficult to grasp. Getting from one's wireframes to a working user interface was quite the ordeal, only intensified by the fact that one's Photoshop layers didn't directly map to HTML elements. The following quote best describes my issues with Angular:

With Angular 1, it felt like the rabbit hole always went deeper. The more I learned, the more there was to learn. Compiling elements by hand, intercepting the digest cycle, and learning all these Angular internals
Here's a depiction of the general learning cycle associated with Angular:
angularjs_curve

Only in my case, I never reached the “OMG That's Awesome!” plateau. Doomed by my friends ill-choice in stack technologies, I looked for better alternatives. To my fortune, I came across Metoer.js earlier this year. Meteor.js takes what MEAN Stack initiated and develops it further by integrating server-side and client-side code into a “do-it-all” environment. It came as a breath of fresh air to me but, even so, it still didn't quite quell the key issues I had with the MEAN stack, and it's “do-it-all” wasn't compatible with today's front-end/back-end separation of concerns. Accepting that this was the best framework on the market, I saw it as the best framework for Tekuma's technology platform. That was until I came across React.js
React is the front-end framework designers have longed for. Except it's not really a framework. Reacts' website describes it like this:

React is a JavaScript library for creating user interfaces. Many people choose to think of React as the V in the MVC [Model-View-Controller]. We built React to solve one problem: building large applications with data that changes over time.

It's developers, Facebook and Instagram, describe it as a library not a framework because , out of the box, frameworks like Angular offer a lot more functionality in comparison to React. However because of the React's large open-source community, it's easy to find a component for almost any functionality your heart desires. This in itself is a benefit, because it abstracts away the complicated details of implementing commonly expected functionality such as “Drag and Drop” or Routing that would otherwise halt consistent development for a beginner developer.

React's spin on UI design doesn't end there  there are many significant differences React benefits from, which many other front-end technologies lack. Some of these innovations have been so successful that competing frameworks have begun to take a page out of React's book. In no particular order, I have outlined the features that set React apart.
The JSX Syntax

In order for developers to bring the reactivity and richness consumers have become accustomed to through native mobile applications to the web, they've had to integrate the DOM with one or more programming languages. This is the identifying quality of most powerful frameworks. If you've been paying attention, I'm sure you've noticed that I've mentioned this DOM concept twice so far, and I'm sure you're itching for an elaboration. For the sake of keeping all readers in the loop, let me make a quick detour. Wikipedia describes the DOM as follows:

The Document Object Model (DOM) is a cross-platform and language-independent application programming interface that treats an HTML, XHTML, or XML document as a tree structure where each node is an object representing a part of the document. The objects can be manipulated programmatically and any visible changes occurring as a result may then be reflected in the display of the document.
asset.reference: Wikipedia, Document Object Model, Wikimedia Foundation, Published: July 31, 2017. Date Accessed: August 11, 2017.

asset.data: dom_tree

Briefly, HTML is used to mark-up web pages. If a website were a house, HMTL would be its foundation. Now that we've got that out way, let's return to the idea of marrying HTML with a programming language. Most frameworks don't necessarily use the same programming language. Over the last couple of years however, we have seen a proliferation of frameworks written in JavaScript, which as a result has become the de facto language of the web. Because HTML and JavaScript developed independently, most frameworks have found different ways to marry the two. One of those ways is by incorporating JavaScript into HTML markup. This is the method favored by Angular.js. There are problems to this method, though, which are best explained by the following extract:

the stuff Angular understands in its HTML is not quite real JS. It's a subset. And that abstraction is leaky. It works great, until it doesn't. You end up second-guessing the code you're typing into those strings. On top of the JS-like syntax, there's the stuff that isn't JS at all. Angular 1 had things like ng-repeat=”item in items” and ng-click=”doStuff()”. Angular 2 switched it up a bit because people found the Angular directives confusing, so now it's ngFor=”let item of items”.

Not fun. Consequently, the developers of React decided to take the complete opposite route by bringing HTML to JavaScript, and they've benefited greatly from their astute choice. They've done this by creating a syntax called JSX, which looks like XML mixed with regular JavaScript code. This method of integration is convenient because it allows developers to define those tree structures inherent to the DOM within their JavaScript code. As a result, your HTML markup is able to leverage the power of JavaScript, giving you more flexibility and control. In addition, for developers conversant with functional programming concepts, the use of the map, filter, reduce methods within the syntax to manipulate data sets seems almost intuitive. Below is an example of the JSX syntax:
Components

The reason I believe React is the perfect paintbrush for UI design boils down to this feature of the library. In React, developers are encouraged to break up their code into small, manageable, reusable fragments called components. This practice is crucial because:

data: From a programming standpoint, having many smaller components that build up to form one's UI makes it much easier to maintain one's code through modularity.
It helps one debug their application, test their application incrementally, and reason about one's code.

It abstracts away the details of a given UI element, giving developers the ability to create their own components that one can later reuse, combine, nest, and share to their heart's content, and in the process keep with the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle.
Components and their behaviors are independent and remain encapsulated.
By breaking down your application  and the DOM  into smaller components, it becomes easer to imagine building a complex application.

From a design standpoint, developers can build their User Interface component by component, similar to how it would be done in any Adobe Creative Suite application. Layers in Photoshop are now directly mappable to fragments of code.

asset.data: State, Data-Binding, and the React Lifecycle

This is probably my favorite React concept. React is declarative of how it handles state. The developers of React have miraculously made a “hard-to-grapple” concept, such as state, very intuitive and easy to understand. Part of the reason this is even possible is because they decided to implement a simple data model and flow. Where most frameworks choose to employ a two-way data binding model (hi Angular), React has opted for a one-way data binding model. To illustrate the differences between the two, I will have to briefly elaborate on the MVC (Model-View-Controller) pattern.
mvc_model

At heart, the MVC is a pattern employed by most GUI (Graphic User Interface) programs as a method to separate the concerns of the application. It separates the user interface (front-end) from the application (back-end), by putting the back-end code into the model and the front-end code into the view and controller. The model is responsible for maintaining application-specific data and providing access to that data, while the view queries the model for data in order to update the user interface to reflect the state of the most recent data.

In an application that employs a two-way binding model, a change to the view is able to mutate the model data, and visa versa. In an application with one-way binding, such as React, this can only be done in one direction. In the case of React, this is via the view mutating the model (or state).

This brings us to how react treats state. State is component-specific, meaning that a given component's state is packaged along with its rendering function and methods. While, theoretically, all components in React could hold state, this is not the case  one of React's best practices is to keep as many components as possible stateless, and isolate state into as few places as possible. This is done to minimize complexity and keep your application as clean as possible. This is the reason why one is able to comfortably reuse, combine, nest, and share components without the fear of bugs.

“But how do you know which components should have state and which should be stateless?” Generally speaking, your app state will correspond to your UI structure. I know that sounds rather vague, but in practice, the decision becomes reasonably intuitive. “But what if a given component's behavior relies on the state of another component?” React deals with this by allowing components to share state through immutable properties called Props (passed properties). If you imagine your application as a tree structure, components higher in the tree (parent components) can pass down their state variables and methods to child components. However, the reverse is not true due to React's unidirectional data flow. As a result, data is passed down and events are triggered up through event handlers.

Imagine a simple application containing a light bulb and a light switch. Ideally, the light bulb and switch would be two separate, stateless child components contained within a parent component with state. The parent component would keep track of the state of the switch (this.switchPressed), i.e. whether it is pressed or not. This state would be passed down to both child elements as props  the light switch would, in addition to the state, receive a toggle method (this.toggleSwitch) to mutate the value of the App state variable when the switch is clicked. This method would be tied to the switch as an event handler and respond to any click events on the light switch. As a result, when a user clicks the switch (an event), the this.props.toggleSwitch() method would be called by the event handler. This is an example of events triggering up the application. The method would then be invoked, toggling the switch state from “off” (false) to “on” (true), which in turn would be passed down to both child elements. The lightbulb would act on this new state by automatically re-rendering to the “light on” state, while the switch would act by automatically re-rendering to the “pressed in” state. In this way, information can be passed back-and-forth between components.
simple_react_tree

You can imagine how this concept might scale into larger applications. It's important to remember that props are immutable (read-only), and cannot be re-assigned values. They can only be changed by invoking prop methods passed down from the parent element which, in turn, should call a special function called this.setState() within them to mutate the state variable tied to the props variable in question. In my opinion, this is a very simple and intuitive way of handling state.

These concepts are taken further by special methods called React Lifecycle methods. These methods are characteristic to all React components and allow us to hook into the views when specific conditions occur (e.g. when the component first renders or when the component is updated with new data). There are many lifecycle methods, but the most important ones are the invoked when a component is mounted/unmounted to the DOM, and when it receives new data.
Mounting/Unmounting

These lifecycle methods are invoked only once during the life of a component and are generally used to establish default props in our components, make Ajax requests to fetch needed data, or set up/remove any listeners. The methods in question are:

The first two methods run when the component is initially rendered, but there is a subtle difference between the two: componentWillMount is invoked when the component is first invoked, while componentDidMount is only invoked when its children components have been successfully rendered. Therefore, if a child element fails to render, the component will fail to call this method.
New Data
These lifecycle methods are invoked whenever a component receives new data from its parent component:

The first method is used when you want to execute code whenever your component receives new props, while the second method is used only for advanced optimization purposes. By default, this method will always run causing a re-render to occur. However, if you have an intimate understanding of when your application needs to re-render, you can use this method to prevent it from re-rendering in all other cases where it doesn't need to re-render. As a result, this improves the apps performance.
While I've only touched on five of the lifecycle methods, the diagram below highlights the entire React lifecycle chain:
react_lifecycle

That's a mouthful! Before beginning this article, I thought I'd have an easy time describing the “ins-and-outs” of React in a succinct and easy-to-understand manner, but I've come to realize that there are many intricacies surrounding these features. I think it's best to look at this article as an introduction to a “framework” that's changing the way we view UI design on the web. If I've enticed your appetite, I encourage you to seek out more information about React. I can assure you, React and its ecosystem have many more treats in store (shout out to Babel, ES6, and arrow functions). As a student birthed by the arts and groomed by the sciences, I can confidently say that React is a sweet marriage of the two worlds, and it's because of this that I implore you to try it for yourself! Once you've picked it up, I guarantee you won't have any more issues painting future UI's.

The fact that you can open up any JavaScript file with a React component in it and understand all the possible states of that component and exactly how it's going to behave just by looking at the file, is incredibly powerful.

asset.data: The Ten Club was founded in 1927 by the then principal, Hubert Kidd, and it was originally named “The Literary and Sociological Society”. As per tradition, membership is limited to 10 matrics elected at the end of their Grade 11 year and it is comprised of the top 5 academics and 5 elected academics from that year, voted in by the outgoing Ten Club Members. Boys elected to the Ten Club are expected to present for 30 minutes on a topic of their choice. This encourages significant research and development that is crucial to life in the academic world. Boys in this society are granted a maroon tie with gold crosses on it (representing the Roman numeral 10) with the letters “TC” incorporated into it.
